Microphones with this pattern capture the majority of their sound from the front and reject sound at the rear. This pattern helps isolate the mic from ambient sound, providing resistance to feedback. Supercardioid/Hypercardioid A variation on the cardioid response pattern, this pattern has a narrower focus in the front but includes some pickup of sound coming from the rear of the microphone. Being highly directional, microphones with this pattern are sometimes referred to as shotgun microphones. When getting together your packing list for the gig, be prepared for as many eventualities as you can anticipate. Take a range of cables and adapters, especially for your recording interface and even if you are taking a feed from the FOH console. Extension power cords are a must as well. You just never know how far away from a power source youre going to be. Once at the venue, set up your own audience mics to capture the room and overall ambience. A direct feed from the stage mics rarely has this kind of spill, and a live recording always needs to include the energy of a cheering audience before or after a song. Consider bringing a backup system for recording. The worst thing that can happen is the DAW dropping outand the worst thing happens from time to time. Ideally, the backup system is associated with a separate signal chain. For instance, your main recording system is connected to the FOH console, while your backup system is connected to the foldback or monitoring system. In this scenario, should there be any problem with the connection to the primary console, you could pull in the foldback signal, which is identical. Live performance recording can use stage-box splitter snakes, where the signals from the stage are sent both to the FOH console and to a series of mobile preamps linked to digital systems, including foldback monitoring and workstation software. Having a breakout and your own preamps allows you much more control over the recorded signal because you are bypassing the EQ and other settings associated with the FOH sound that are applied to generate a good live sound. Warren Huart and Jerry Hammack performance will impact how they perform. If the musicians you are working with have a unique sound that serves as a signature of sorts, any preference you personally may have should always be secondary to what best serves the artist. For instance, if the drummer has great feel, you dont want to squash it with compression all those dynamics are why the player is great in the first place. In those situations, a little touch of compression on the snare top and the kick drums inside mic will tighten things without killing the dynamics. Thinking about piling on the compression when working with a super-dynamic jazz drummer? Dont even. Always keep in mind that your use of EQ and especially dynamics in recording the dominant instruments of your arrangement (drums, bass, guitars, keys) will impact how other instruments must be recorded to fit in and be heard. When it comes to music that is a blend of organic and virtual instruments, the dynamic ranges can be mismatched completely, and the sounds wont work together. Wall-of-amps guitars dont sit well with jazz drums. Dynamic acoustic guitars dont tend to sit well with in- your-face virtual drums. In either case, adding some compression to even out the relationship between sounds will not only improve the balance but also allow the musician to approach their work more naturally, because they wont be trying to compete with the louder, less dynamic elements. With all that said, some decisions you can make in recording arent necessary. If youre considering squashing up room mics with compression to develop some secondary energy, for example, you can easily do this in the mixing phase too. 208

It signature tones. uses two single-coil pickups that are wound in opposite directions. The dual-pickup design means that twice the signal is being generated by the pickup, so its loud. The design also means the polarity of the first coil is cancelled by the second, silencing the noise from the pickup (bucking the hum). Active pickups use fewer coils than their passive cousins, making them quieter, though they produce less output. To make up for it, their circuitry uses an active preamp to increase the signal level (typically powered by a nine- volt battery). Because the overall signal level is boosted by a preamp, these pickups have less dynamic range than passive pickups do. A Gibson Les Paul Gold Top solid body guitar and Epiphone Casino thinline hollow body guitar Along with the body type and tonewoods, guitar pickups are the arguably the greatest influencer over the tone of the instrument before it hits the amplifier. Pickups are wire-wound magnets emitting an electrical field intersected by the guitar strings. When a string is played, its vibration alters the field, and the resulting electric signal is relayed through tone and volume filters, out of the guitar and into the amplifier. Home Studio Recording: The Complete Guide MIDI also allows you to revoice entire arrangements at will. What started as an EDM number with a dozen vintage synthesisers as virtual instruments can just as easily be played with a virtual symphony orchestra or a full complement of ethnocentric world instruments. The enormous flexibility offered by virtual instruments in creating music in these styles is both its blessing and its curse. You can literally get lost in choosing between a hundred different drum sounds, piano makes and models, synths and more. To the greatest extent possible, its still a good idea, even with this form of music, to think about the stages of music production and your intent for the song. As with any other recording in any other genre, be sure the song comes first. A beat is not a song. A phrase is not a song. Once you have a song, you have a framework to hang your ideas on, and it will help keep you from getting lost in the endless variety of options available to you and your artist. So while you can start right in on recording your song (even doing so with your artist), its best to start your recording with a finished song or to make finishing the song job number one of the recording sessions. 259

Many reverb plugins have this parameter, and it functions by separating the dry signal from the wet signal via a user-set time interval, meant to represent the early reflection of sound off of the nearest surface. Using Artificial Double-Tracking Double-tracking is almost as old as recording itselfduplicating a performance creates interesting phase relationships between the original and doubled performance and is especially nice on vocals. Tools such as Waves Doubler and Reel ADT can give a single vocal performance that double-tracked feel. Waves Doubler uses delay and pitch modulation (chorusing) to automatically add texture and richness to a single track, while Reel ADT replicates EMI Studios famed Artificial Double Tracking (ADT) hardware setup invented by Ken Townsend for John Lennon. They are both great ways to add variation to a vocal mix, thickening up the chorus, or even to use as an overall effect on the vocal. 349

Warren Huart and Jerry Hammack Now that youve reached the end of our book, we want to encourage you and share our hopes for you. We hope that you will continue to refer to this book as you develop your pro audio skills. Its a lot to digest all at once, but weve designed it so you can dip in and out of topics as you need to and as you reach different milestones in your journey. If you want to make great music, we want to encourage you to keep on learning. Be humble and open to new information and knowledge and, perhaps most of all, remember that its not about youits about the music. There are so many great books that can help you understand how the greats in our industry think about their work, including autobiographies from Phil Ramone (Making Recordsprobably the best book of all time on understanding how to work with artists and musicians) to Al Schmitt (On the Record: The Magic Behind the Music) to George Martin (Playback and All You Need Is Ears). Theres no reason for excuses. If you want to be a really good, complete producer or mixer, then all it takes is putting in the effort to learn different ways to work and record, and putting that knowledge into practice. There is an ever-growing goldmine of information and examples available to you to draw from online and in print. Joining communities like our Produce Like A Pro Academy and Pro Mix Academy will help you learn from the experiences of your peers. We want to encourage you, as best you can, to integrate these lessons into your musical life. We also want to remind you that your journey is your own unique one. The progress you make, how and when you make it, are all in your hands and in your time. We hope this book is a companion for you on your journey and it inspires you to learn and develop new skills, expand your mind, experiment and nurture your talent and the talents of others. We hope that it encourages you to reach out when you have questions and help others when you have answers. We hope that it frees you to join in community with others who are just like you and just like ussharing a love for music and a desire to contribute more of it to the world. We hope it helps you to create meaningful music with a positive spirit and pride of craftmanship. Most of all, we hope you have a marvellous time recording, mixing, mastering and making music.  Warren Huart and Jerry Hammack 410
